Prompt:
Example 1:
Daniel was but eight years old, a boy of striking appearance, with black hair and eyes, and a swarthy complexion. He was of slender frame, and his large dark eyes, deep set beneath an overhanging brow, gave a singular appearance to the thin face of the delicate looking boy. He was a farmer's son, and lived in a plain, old-fashioned house, shaded by fine elms, and separated from the broad, quiet street by a fence. It was situated in a valley, at the bend of the Merrimac, on both sides of which rose high hills, which the boy climbed many a time for the more extended view they commanded. From a high sheep-pasture on his father's farm, through a wide opening in the hills, he could see on a clear day Brentney Mountain in Vermont, and in a different direction the snowy top of Mount Washington, far away to the northeast.

Example 2:
There is no specific scientific calculator prescribed for this subject. Any scientific, nonprogrammable calculator is suitable for your studies. Different scientific calculators have different functions and it is up to you to know your calculator. Most scientific calculators have algebraic logic; the operation in an expression can be entered in the calculator in the order in which the expression is read (left to right). The calculator automatically follows the conventional order of operations. 
You can setup your calculator to work either in natural display or linear display. Natural display causes fractions, irrational numbers, expressions, and certain functions to be displayed as you see them on paper. Linear display causes fractions and other expressions to be displayed in a line. 
When we come across an expression such as 7 + 3 ÷ 10 × 1, it makes a difference how we choose which operations to perform first.
Scientific calculators have been programmed to follow preset mathematical rules. If we press the buttons in a certain order, the calculator does the operations according to the rules that it has been programmed with.

The study of the stars, planets, and galaxies is called astronomy. Astronomers are scientists who explore the universe to understand its workings and composition. They study celestial bodies, their movements, and interactions. From a high hill or a mountain, one can observe the stars on a clear night, and on a good day, the planets and the moon. With a telescope or a pair of binoculars, the details of the universe become clearer. By studying the night sky, astronomers can gain a deeper understanding of the universe and its many mysteries. Astronomy, the study of celestial objects, has long fascinated humans. From ancient civilizations to modern times, people have gazed up at the stars, wondering about the mysteries of the universe. The field has evolved significantly, with advancements in technology allowing for more precise observations and discoveries. Today, astronomers use a range of tools, including telescopes and computers, to study the behavior of planets, stars, and galaxies. By understanding the universe, we can gain insights into its origins, evolution, and ultimate fate, expanding our knowledge of the cosmos and our place within it. Its study continues to captivate and inspire.  The study of astronomy has also led to numerous practical applications, such as GPS technology and weather forecasting. Astronomy is the study of the physical nature of celestial bodies, including planets, stars, galaxies, and comets. From a high point on the earth's surface, an astronomer can observe the stars and constellations in the night sky, learning about their relative positions and movements. With the aid of powerful telescopes, astronomers can study the details of the sun, moon, and planets, gaining insights into their composition, temperature, and other properties. By studying the universe, astronomers seek to understand the laws that govern the behavior of celestial bodies. This knowledge can lead to a deeper understanding of the universe's origin and evolution. Daniel was but eight years old, a boy of striking appearance, with black hair and eyes, and a swarthy complexion. He was of slender frame, and his large dark eyes, deep set beneath an overhanging brow, gave a singular appearance to the thin face of the delicate looking boy. He was a farmer's son, and lived in a plain, old-fashioned house, shaded by fine elms, and separated from the broad, quiet street by a fence. It was situated in a valley, at the bend of the Merrimac, on both sides of which rose high hills, which the boy climbed many a time for the more extended view they commanded. From a high sheep-pasture on his father's farm, through a wide opening in the hills, he could see on a clear day Brentney Mountain in Vermont, and in a different direction the snowy top of Mount Washington, far away to the northeast.

Example 2:
There is no specific scientific calculator prescribed for this subject. Any scientific, nonprogrammable calculator is suitable for your studies. Different scientific calculators have different functions and it is up to you to know your calculator. Most scientific calculators have algebraic logic; the operation in an expression can be entered in the calculator in the order in which the expression is read (left to right). The calculator automatically follows the conventional order of operations. 
You can setup your calculator to work either in natural display or linear display. Natural display causes fractions, irrational numbers, expressions, and certain functions to be displayed as you see them on paper. Linear display causes fractions and other expressions to be displayed in a line. 
When we come across an expression such as 7 + 3 ÷ 10 × 1, it makes a difference how we choose which operations to perform first.
Scientific calculators have been programmed to follow preset mathematical rules. If we press the buttons in a certain order, the calculator does the operations according to the rules that it has been programmed with.

Astronomy is the study of the universe and celestial objects. Astronomers observe and analyze the stars, planets, galaxies, and other objects in space. They use powerful telescopes and computers to gather data and make predictions about the behavior of these objects. By studying the universe, astronomers gain a deeper understanding of the laws of physics and the origins of the cosmos. From the surface of the sun to the farthest reaches of the galaxy, astronomy offers a unique perspective on the vast and mysterious universe that surrounds us. It is a fascinating field of study.  .

Astronomy is the study of celestial objects and phenomena. From a high vantage point, a stargazer can see on a clear night the stars and planets in our solar system. With the aid of a telescope, one can observe distant galaxies and nebulas. By studying the night sky, astronomers can learn about the composition and structure of celestial bodies. The study of astronomy has led to many important discoveries, including the understanding of the life cycle of stars and the existence of black holes. By exploring the universe, astronomers can gain a deeper understanding of the cosmos and its mysteries.  (100 words)
